Season ! Episodes ! First Air Date ! Last Air Date ! DVD Release Date |- | [[List of The Naked Brothers Band episodes#Season 1: 2007|Season 1]] | align="center" |13 | February 3, 2007 | October 20, 2007 | January 8, 2008 |- | [[List of The Naked Brothers Band episodes#Season 2 : 2008|Season 2]] | align="center" |15 | January 21, 2008 | June 6, 2008 | October 21, 2008 |- | [[List of The Naked Brothers Band episodes#Season 3: 2008 - 2009|Season 3]] | align="center" |12 | October 18, 2008 | June 13, 2009 | N/A |} ==Awards== In 2005, ''The Naked Brothers Band: The Movie'' won the audience award for a family feature film at the [[Hamptons International Film Festival]]. Of Hecht's attendance, he said, "I could see there was an audience for this. They're real kids, real brothers, making real music."{{cite news|url=http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20160775,00.html|title=Hanging Out with ... the Naked Brothers Band|author=Dagostino, Mark|publisher=''[[People Magazine]]''|date=November 5, 2007|accessdate=2009-06-15|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090602061226/http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20160775,00.html|archive-date=2009-06-02|dead-url=no|df=}} Draper received a [[Writers Guild Award]] nomination for the episode [[Nat is a Stand-Up Guy (TV episode)|"Nat is a Stand-Up Guy"]] in the section of [[Writers Guild of America Awards 2007#Children's|Children's]] [[Writers Guild of America Awards 2007#Episodic & specials|Episodic and Specials]] in 2008.{{cite news|url=http://www.wga.org/subpage_newsevents.aspx?id=2653|title=2008 TV and radio nominees announced|publisher=''[[Writers Guild of America]]''|date=December 12, 2007|accessdate=2009-06-15|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071219203806/http://www.wga.org/subpage_newsevents.aspx?id=2653|archivedate=December 19, 2007|df=}} The following year, in 2009, the TV movie ''[[Polar Bears (TV movie)|Polar Bears]]'' won Draper a WGA for [[Writers Guild of America Awards 2008#Long Form or Special|Children's Script — Long Form or Special]]; it was the only one nominated in the category.{{cite news|url=http://www.wga.org/awards/awardssub.aspx?id=1517|title=wga awards|publisher=''Writers Guild of America''|year=2009|accessdate=2009-06-25|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060412082516/http://www.wga.org/awards/awardssub.aspx?id=1517|archivedate=2006-04-12|df=}} In 2007, Nat was nominated for Best TV Actor at the Nickelodeon Kids' Choice Awards in the [[Nickelodeon UK Kids' Choice Awards|United Kingdom]].{{cite web|url=http://www.nickkcapress.com/2007KCA/|title=KCA Around the World / Nickelodeon Kids' Choice Awards 2007 Press Kit|publisher=''Nick.com''|accessdate=2009-06-28|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141018175159/http://www.nickkcapress.com/2007KCA/|archive-date=2014-10-18|dead-url=no|df=}} Moreover, the adult Wolff and his sons received a [[Broadcast Music, Inc.]] Cable Award for their work on the show's music. In 2008, the series' cast performed at the [[2008 Kids' Choice Awards|KCAs in United States]]; the following year, Nat was nominated for Favorite TV Actor.{{cite web|url=http://www.nick.com/kids-choice-awards/nat-wolff-biography.jhtml|title=Nat Wolff – Biography – Kids' Choice Awards 2009|publisher=''Nick.com''|accessdate=2009-06-28|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090715073443/http://www.nick.com/kids-choice-awards/nat-wolff-biography.jhtml|archive-date=2009-07-15|dead-url=no|df=}} ==Reception== {|class="toccolours" style="float: right; margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 2em; font-size: 85%; background:#c6dbf7; color:black; width:40em; max-width: 35%;" cellspacing="5" |style="text-align: left;"|"The songs, actually written by Nat, may not top the charts, but they're far more tolerable than [[Kidz Bop]] and are hard to shake once the show is over. Amazingly, all of the kids here [are] real musicians. If Draper really wants to create a show business legacy, she should sell her secrets on how to get kids to practice their musical instruments." |- |style="text"-align: left;"|—Laura Fries from ''Variety'' |} Albie Hecht foreshadowed the success of the series after watching the film at the Hamptons International Film Festival. In an article, Hecht told ''[[The New York Times|New York Times]]'' reporter Felicia R. Lee: "They're just real: real brothers, real friends; it's all the stuff kids do when they're hanging out on the playground. The idea that you're watching a documentary is so much fun. Then you put them into that fantasy of being a world-famous rock band, and that's the sauce that makes it work." Lee also called both the film and television series, "an ebullient mock documentary." In October 2006, online videos from their Nickelodeon website had been played over 11 million times. Moreover, before the show's debut, "a fan recognized Nat and Alex in a Florida hotel. She sent them a note: 'Are you the Naked Brothers?' 'They were so excited,' Draper recalled. 'The show hasn't even aired yet and now walking down the streets kids are calling out their names. They can't believe it.' " When the film premiered on the network, it was seen by an average of 2.7 million viewers, and placed the top 10 spot on the ''[[Nielsen VideoScan]]'' children's non-theatrical DVD charts.{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/life/television/news/2007-01-30-nielsens-analysis_x.htm|title=Viewers are kind to 'Idol'|publisher=''[[USA Today]]''|date=January 30, 2007|accessdate=2009-06-14|first=Gary|last=Levin|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121024164622/http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/life/television/news/2007-01-30-nielsens-analysis_x.htm|archive-date=2012-10-24|dead-url=no|df=}} The movie was also broadcast four times, producing a total viewership of 14 million.{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/02/02/AR2007020201796.html|title='Naked Brothers,' Ready for Much More Exposure|author=Frey, Jennifer|work=[[Washington Post]]|date=February 3, 2007|accessdate=January 30, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305031759/http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/02/02/AR2007020201796.html|archive-date=2016-03-05|dead-url=no|df=}} The band's hit song "Crazy Car" sold more than 100,000 downloads online; it was placed on the top 100 ''[[Billboard Charts]]'' for seven weeks and the track was featured on the ''Nickelodeon's Kids' Choice, Vol 3''.{{cite web|url=http://www.nickkcapress.com/2007KCA/soundtrack.php|title=KCA Soundtrack Release / Nickelodeon Kids' Choice Awards 2007 Press Kit|publisher=''[[2007 Kids' Choice Awards|Nickelodeon Kids' Choice Awards 2007]]''|date=March 20, 2007|accessdate=2009-06-15|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090618121113/http://www.nickkcapress.com/2007KCA/soundtrack.php|archive-date=2009-06-18|dead-url=no|df=}} According to a 2007 [[PRNewswire]] article, the show "quickly became one of the top programs for tweens on television." The series is in a popular category of children's TV shows, along with [[Disney Channel]]'s ''[[Hannah Montana (TV series)|Hannah Montana]]'' and ''[[Cory in the House]]''. By October 2007, Nick.com's message boards had 5.3 million pages viewed, causing online madness. The show has three [[video games]] online that have been played about 24 million times. Moreover, fans have downloaded over 800 thousand podcasts. {|class="toccolours" style="float: left; margin-right: 1em; margin-right: 2em; font-size: 85%; background:#c6dbf7; color:black; width:30em; max-width: 35%;" cellspacing="5" |style="text-align: left;"|"They could really do well. In the past, Nickelodeon properties had done OK, but they have not really had huge successes like Disney's ''[[Hannah Montana]]'' or ''[[High School Musical]]'', but the viewership numbers for the Naked Brothers are promising and they could be the ones to break through." |- |style="text"-align: left;"|—Geoff Mayfield, director of charts and senior analyst of ''[[Billboard Magazine]]'' |} The premiere of the series acquired the channel as favorable for children aged 6–11; ''[[Nielsen Media Research]]'' calculates—of in that age range—approximately 1.3 million people have watched the first 10 episodes of the series. For all ages, most of the first season attracted approximately 2.8 million viewers per week. It was one of the quickest starts in about three decades for the network.{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p887728/biography|pure_url=yes}}|title=The Naked Brothers Band – Biography|author=Phares, Heather|publisher=[[Allmusic]]|accessdate=2009-06-22}} The evening the show debuted on the channel aired two episodes, averaging out to a total viewership of 3.7 million. The first one, "VMA's", drew exactly 3.5 million viewers. The next airing was "Wolff Brother's Cry Wolff" which garnered a sum of 3.8 million viewers; the episode gave the channel its most favorable ratings in seven years.{{cite news|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/nickelodeons-the-naked-brothers-band-rock-in-the-ratings-and-earn-network-its-highest-rated-premiere-in-seven-years-54494827.html|title=Nickelodeon's The Naked Brothers Band Rock in the Ratings and Earn Network its Highest Rated Premiere in Seven Years|work=PRNewswire|date=February 6, 2007|accessdate=December 10, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131213213958/http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/nickelodeons-the-naked-brothers-band-rock-in-the-ratings-and-earn-network-its-highest-rated-premiere-in-seven-years-54494827.html|archive-date=2013-12-13|dead-url=no|df=}} From February 12 to 18 in 2007, repeats for the series garnered 4 million viewers; it was the sixth most watched program for the week.{{cite news|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/life/television/nielsen-more.htm|title=TV: Expanded Nielsen ratings, Feb. 12-18|work=[[USA Today]]|date=February 21, 2007|accessdate=January 30, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130409230155/http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/life/television/nielsen-more.htm|archive-date=2013-04-09|dead-url=no|df=}} For all ages, the premiere of the season one TV movie "[[Battle of the Bands (TV movie)|Battle of the Bands]]" was quite successful, garnering a viewership of exactly 3.8 million.{{cite news|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/nickelodeons-the-naked-brothers-band-battle-of-the-bands-rocks-the-ratings-as-weeks-top-show-with-kids-and-tweens-58481097.html|title=Nickelodeon's The Naked Brothers Band: Battle of the Bands Rocks the Ratings as Week's Top Show With Kids and Tweens|work=PRNewswire|date=October 9, 2007|accessdate=December 10, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131213213955/http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/nickelodeons-the-naked-brothers-band-battle-of-the-bands-rocks-the-ratings-as-weeks-top-show-with-kids-and-tweens-58481097.html|archive-date=2013-12-13|dead-url=no|df=}} The second season TV movie "Sidekicks" debuted to a total of 3.6 million viewers,{{cite news|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/nickelodeons-the-naked-brothers-band-season-two-premiere-rocks-to-the-top-of-broadcast-and-cable-with-tweens-kids-6-11-57313682.html|title=Nickelodeon's The Naked Brothers Band Season Two Premiere Rocks to the Top of Broadcast and Cable with Tweens, Kids 6-11|work=PRNewswire|date=January 24, 2008|accessdate=December 10, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131213214151/http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/nickelodeons-the-naked-brothers-band-season-two-premiere-rocks-to-the-top-of-broadcast-and-cable-with-tweens-kids-6-11-57313682.html|archive-date=2013-12-13|dead-url=no|df=}} with the season's finale TV movie "[[Polar Bears (TV movie)|Polar Bears]]" drawing 1.7 million viewers for children aged 6–11; the latter was the second most watched show for the week in that age group.{{cite news|url=http://www.medialifemagazine.com/ruling-class-our-richest-tween-celebs/|title=Ruling class: Our richest tween celebs - Five faves make the Forbes Celebrity 100 list|author=Fitzgerald, Toni|work=[[Media Life Magazine]]|date=June 12, 2008|accessdate=January 31, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140202221435/http://www.medialifemagazine.com/ruling-class-our-richest-tween-celebs/|archive-date=2014-02-02|dead-url=no|df=}} The series flourished the most with the airing of the season three TV movie "Mystery Girl", producing a viewership of 4 million.{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=akH0SVoldTmU|title=Nickelodeon's New Season of The Naked Brothers Band Rocks as Nickelodeon's New Season of The Naked Brothers Band Rocks as Week's Top Live-Action Show With Kids and Tweens|work=[[Bloomberg News]]|date=October 21, 2008|accessdate=December 10, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131228141836/http://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=akH0SVoldTmU|archive-date=2013-12-28|dead-url=no|df=}} A month later, the TV movie "Operation Mojo" was broadcast to an audience of 2.8 million viewers.{{cite news|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/missing-headline-123583|title=Missing Headline|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|date=November 26, 2008|access-date=2013-12-10|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140302115500/http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/missing-headline-123583|archive-date=2014-03-02|dead-url=no|df=}} When the season three TV special "Valentine Dream Date" aired, it was also successful; exactly 3.2 million viewers watched it.{{cite news|url=http://ir.viacom.com/releasedetail.cfm?ReleaseID=628609|title=Nickelodeon's 'Crush Night' Featuring David Archuleta is Weekend's Biggest Kid, Tween Event; New iCarly Tops Broadcast, Cable TV for Week|work=[[Viacom]]|date=February 10, 2009|accessdate=December 10, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131214023555/http://ir.viacom.com/releasedetail.cfm?ReleaseID=628609|archive-date=2013-12-14|dead-url=no|df=}} The executive vice president of development and original programming for Nickelodeon, Marjorie Cohn explains: "The premiere of ''The Naked Brothers Band'' series has exploded and continues to grow in popularity as a multiplatform and international property for Nickelodeon." She also notes, prior to broadcasting the second season, that "Nat and Alex are bonafide rock stars who have captured the hearts of kids everywhere with their original music and we're excited to kick off a brand-new season of their hit series. This season finds the band prepping for their tour while still having the same ups and downs of kid-dom that their fans at home are experiencing. It's this authenticity that's the appeal of the show—plus the music is irresistible."{{cite news|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/nickelodeon-keeps-on-rocking-with-season-two-premiere-of-the-hit-mockumentary-series-the-naked-brothers-band-monday-jan-21-at-800-pm-etpt-56894837.html|title=Nickelodeon Keeps on Rocking With Season Two Premiere of the Hit Mockumentary Series, The Naked Brothers Band, Monday, Jan. 21, at 8:00 P.M. (ET/PT)|work=PRNewswire|date=January 14, 2008|accessdate=September 26, 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130624062159/http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/nickelodeon-keeps-on-rocking-with-season-two-premiere-of-the-hit-mockumentary-series-the-naked-brothers-band-monday-jan-21-at-800-pm-etpt-56894837.html|archive-date=2013-06-24|dead-url=no|df=}} The family had encountered an incident in the past; they had to delist and change their phone number in [[New York City|Lower Manhattan]] because fans worldwide were calling their apartment relentlessly. Draper recalls, "Little girls would call and say, 'Helloooo, is [Nat] there? We just love him.' The only thing that's comforting is, they're pretty harmless at that age." According to Nat, "After the show came on, people began to really treat us like huge rock stars. They'd scream on the street, and we'd look behind us to see what they were screaming about, because we didn't realize it was us." Despite the show's prosperity—in terms of its viewership ratings, as it came close to wrap up filming for the third season, network bosses urged the family to lengthen the season from 13 episodes to 60. Nevertheless, prior agreements had already been made between Draper, her husband and the staff at Nickelodeon that shooting would not interfere with the boys' school schedule. Network executives chose no longer to conform to the family's demands, prompting Draper and Wolff to cancel the series in mid-2009. Of the cancellation, no formal announcement had been made by either the family or network until Nat disclosed the incident to the press in 2013. ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== * [http://www.natnalex.com/ The official website of Nat and Alex Wolff] {{Nickelodeon original series and Nicktoons}} {{NBB}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Naked Brothers Band, The}} [[Category:2000s American music television series]] [[Category:2000s American satirical television series]] [[Category:2007 American television series debuts]] [[Category:2009 American television series endings]] [[Category:2000s Nickelodeon shows]] [[Category:American children's comedy television series]] [[Category:English-language television programs]] [[Category:Television series based on singers and musicians]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of people]] [[Category:American mockumentary television series]] [[Category:Reality television series parodies]] [[Category:Television programs based on films]] [[Category:Television series about television]] [[Category:Television shows set in New York City]] [[Category:Musical comedy television programmes]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2015}} {{Use British English|date=August 2015}} {{Italic title}} {{Infobox artwork | image_file = Joseph Wright of Derby Thomas Borrow.jpg | painting_alignment = right | title = Thomas Borrow | alt = | other_language_1 = | other_title_1 = | other_language_2 = | other_title_2 = | artist = [[Joseph Wright of Derby]] | year = {{start date|1762}}-3 | height_metric = 127 | width_metric = 101.6 | length_metric = | height_imperial = | width_imperial = | length_imperial = | diameter_metric = | diameter_imperial = | dimensions = | metric_unit = cm<!--don't leave this parameter blank—either don't include it, or include the default cm. Not including it will default it to cm.--> | imperial_unit = in<!--don't leave this parameter blank—either don't include it, or include the default in. Not including it will default it to in.--> | city = [[Derby]] | museum = [[Derby Museum and Art Gallery]] | coordinates = <!-- Only use for the exact coordinates of the artwork itself (and only where known) and not for the coordinates of the museum. Leave blank if coordinates are not known. --> | owner = }} {{Infobox artwork | image_file = Joseph Wright of Derby Anne Borrow.jpg | painting_alignment = right | title = Anne Borrow | alt = | other_language_1 = | other_title_1 = | other_language_2 = | other_title_2 = | artist = [[Joseph Wright of Derby]] | year = {{start date|1762}}-3 | height_metric = 127 | width_metric = 101.6 | length_metric = | height_imperial = | width_imperial = | length_imperial = | diameter_metric = | diameter_imperial = | dimensions = | metric_unit = cm<!--don't leave this parameter blank—either don't include it, or include the default cm. Not including it will default it to cm.--> | imperial_unit = in<!--don't leave this parameter blank—either don't include it, or include the default in. Not including it will default it to in.--> | city = | museum = [[Derby Museum and Art Gallery]] | coordinates = <!-- Only use for the exact coordinates of the artwork itself (and only where known) and not for the coordinates of the museum. Leave blank if coordinates are not known. --> | owner = }} '''''Thomas Borrow''''' and '''Ann Borrow''' are two paintings by [[Joseph Wright of Derby]].
==Description== Thomas Borrow was the eldest son to Isaac and Honor Borrow and was born on 3 June 1709. His father who resided at Castlefield, a very large country house, was twice [[Mayor of Derby]]<ref name="ptp">[http://www.picturethepast.org.uk/frontend.php?keywords=Ref_No_increment;EQUALS;DMAG200367&pos=2&action=zoom Thomas Borrow], PictureThePast, accessed July 2011</ref> in 1730 and 1742.<ref name=glover>[https://books.google.com/books?id=BsoHAAAAQAAJ&dq=%22edward+mundy%22&lr=&client=firefox-a&pg=RA1-PA16&ci=441,951,114,16&source=bookclip">The history and gazetteer of the county of Derby] By Stephen Glover, 1831, accessed July 2011</ref> There is a painting of Isaac Borrow extant and the Borrow house is included in a 1725 painting called [[A Prospect of Derby]].
Borrow entered Grays Inn in 1727.<ref>[http://www.ebooksread.com/authors-eng/grays-inn-cn/the-register-of-admissions-to-grays-inn-1521-1889-together-with-the-register--yar/page-38-the-register-of-admissions-to-grays-inn-1521-1889-together-with-the-register--yar.shtml Admissions to Grays Inn], accessed July 2011</ref> In the year after Bonnie Prince Charlie came to Derby, Borrow was made the [[Town Clerk]] in 1746.<ref>[http://www.derby.gov.uk/LeisureCulture/MuseumsGalleries/Portrait_of_Thomas_Borrow.htm Portrait of Thomas Borrow] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101030015438/http://www.derby.gov.uk/LeisureCulture/MuseumsGalleries/Portrait_of_Thomas_Borrow.htm |date=30 October 2010 }}, Derby.gov.uk, accessed July 2011</ref>
In 1757 he married Anne Ault of [[Loughborough]] and came into the use of £4,000 and lands and property in [[Litchurch]] and the parish of St Peters.<ref name=na>{{cite web|url=http://www.nationalarchives.gov.uk/a2a/records.aspx?cat=026-d5369&cid=-1#-1|title=Borough Estate and Family Papers - Access to Archives|publisher=The National Archives|accessdate=16 July 2011}}</ref> St Peters parish is now in the centre of Derby. Joseph Wright of Derby painted Borrow and his wife, Anne (or Ann). Both of these paintings are in the collection of [[Derby Museum and Art Gallery]] as is an anonymous painting of their house called ''Castlefields''. The paintings both date from 1762-3 and are 40 by 50 inches in size.
Borrow died on 6 August 1786. They had one son name Thomas who spelt his surname Borough<ref name="ptp"/> and a daughter Anne Honor who died aged twelve. The parents and daughter are buried in [[St Lawrence's Church, Gotham|St Lawrence Church in Gotham]] where there is a memorial on the south wall.<ref>[http://southwellchurches.nottingham.ac.uk/gotham/hmonumnt.php Gotham monuments], Southwell Churches, retrieved 28 July 2014</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Derby Museum}}

{{Infobox Venue | name = Théâtre municipal de Tunis | caption = Facade of the Théâtre municipal de Tunis | image = Théâtre Tunis.JPG | location = [[Tunis]] | type = Indoor [[theater]] | opened = November 20, 1902 | capacity = 1,350 | owner = | former_names = | website = {{URL|theatremunicipal-tunis.gov.tn}} }}
The '''Théâtre municipal de [[Tunis]]''' (engl. ''Municipal Theatre of Tunis'') in [[Tunisia]] was first opened on November 20, 1902 and currently showcases [[opera]], [[ballet]], symphonic concerts and dramas featuring numerous Tunisian, Arabic and international actors.<ref>{{fr}} [http://www.commune-tunis.gov.tn/fr/culture_theatre0.htm Théâtres (Municipalité de Tunis)]</ref>
== Notable events == In June 2013, a [[K-pop]] concert was held at the Théâtre municipal de Tunis by the South Korean boyband [[Lunafly]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Le premier K-Pop groupe Sud Coréen débarque en Tunisie|url=http://www.tekiano.com/kult/musik/7603-le-premier-k-pop-groupe-sud-coreen-debarque-en-tunisie-.html|publisher=Tekiano|accessdate=24 May 2013|language=French}}</ref>
== External links == * [http://www.theatremunicipal-tunis.gov.tn/ Homepage of the Théâtre municipal de Tunis]
==References== <references/>

revision.text:
{{Infobox company |name = UTA Brand Studio |type = [[Private company|Private]] |foundation = [[Beverly Hills, California]], United States (2012) |location = [[Beverly Hills, California]] (USA) |key_people ='''Larry Vincent''', Co-Founder, Chief Branding Officer
'''Michellene DeBonis''', Co-Founder, Executive Vice President Client Development
'''Marcus Bartlett''', Creative Director |homepage = [http://www.utabrandstudio.com http://www.utabrandstudio.com] }} In 2012, '''UTA Brand Studio''' was unveiled as the brand strategy division of [[United Talent Agency]] (UTA), one of the world’s largest literary and talent agencies. The studio is based in UTA’s Beverly Hills, CA headquarters. [[Laurence Vincent]] and Michellene DeBonis are UTA Brand Studio co-founders. Vincent’s 20-year career in branding has included roles with [[Siegel + Gale]] and Octagon, Inc., for such clients as Disney, MasterCard, Microsoft, the NFL, PlayStation and Qualcomm. DeBonis also brings 20 years of brand experience including work for Bare Minerals, Panasonic, Microsoft, Yahoo!, Operation Smile and Susan G. Komen. Other UTA Brand Studio team members include Creative Director R. Marcus Bartlett—who joined the team from Futurebrand where he won a Clio Award for his work with American Airlines—and Director of Client Engagement Catherine Davie. Vincent has written two brand strategy books. In March 2012, ''Brand Real'' was released, focusing on the strategic behavior that drives the success of the world’s leading brands. ''Brand Real'' was recognized by strategy+business magazine as one of the best business books of 2012. In 2001, ''Legendary Brands'' was released, examining the storytelling potential of brands and implications for strategic and creative development.{{cite web|url=http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20140108005857/en/UTA-Brand-Studio-Launches-First-Ever-Brand-Dependence%E2%84%A2 |title=UTA Brand Studio Launches First-Ever Brand Dependence™ Index as Key Predictor of a Brand’s Influence and Potential |publisher=Business Wire |date=2014-01-08 |accessdate=2014-07-23}} ==Brand Attachment Research== In January 2014, a new quantitative research tool measuring brand attachment was launched by UTA Brand Studio. Brand Dependence™ is described as a tool to measure the personal connection consumers have to a brand and the degree to which they see a brand as being part of who they are. Developed in an exclusive partnership with uSamp and UTA Brand Studio, Brand Dependence™ is built upon the pioneering academic research on brand attachment of Deborah MacInnis, Vice Dean and Professor at [[USC Marshall School of Business]] and C. Whan Park Professor of Marketing at USC Marshall School of Business. At CES 2014, the UTA Brand Studio announced the inaugural Brand Dependence™ index focusing on technology brands. Social media brands were examined in the second installment.{{cite web|last=Champagne |first=Christine |url=http://www.fastcocreate.com/3027398/a-new-survey-reveals-which-social-media-brands-people-are-most-attached-to |title=A New Survey Reveals Which Social Media Brands People Are Most Attached To | Co.Create | creativity + culture + commerce |publisher=Fastcocreate.com |date=2014-03-07 |accessdate=2014-07-23}} Some of UTA Brand Studio’s clients include The Elizabeth Taylor Trust, Bare Minerals, Mattel and the Consumer Electronics Association. In 2014, the studio was named a winner of the CLIO Image Awards Shortlist in the Design category on behalf of client The Elizabeth Taylor Trust.{{cite web|url=http://www.clioimage.com/winners/2014/design/entry.cfm?entryid=801410450 |title=CLIO Image Awards 2014 | Winners : Design - Elizabeth Taylor / |publisher=Clioimage.com |date= |accessdate=2014-07-23}} Some of the media outlets that have featured Larry Vincent include [[Forbes]], [[Digiday]] and Ragan.com. Vincent has presented to such groups as CES, SXSW, The Conference Board, CMO Collective, and Digital Hollywood, among others. In April 2014, UTA Brand Studio in conjunction with Live Talks LA hosted Twitter co-founder and Jelly CEO Biz Stone in conversation with Vincent about Stone’s new book THINGS A LITTLE BIRD TOLD ME: CONF Mark.{{cite web|url=http://livetalksla.org/blog/2014/02/16/april-9-biz-stone-co-founder-twitter/ |title=April 9 — Biz Stone, Co-founder, Twitter | Live Talks Los Angeles |publisher=Livetalksla.org |date=2014-04-09 |accessdate=2014-07-23}} == References == ==External links== * [http://utabrandstudio.com UTA Brand Studio] [[Category:Talent and literary agencies]] [[Category:Privately held companies based in California]] [[Category:American companies established in 2012]] [[Category:Companies based in Beverly Hills, California]]

'''Vampire Cowboys Theatre Company''' is an [[Obie Award]] and [[New York Innovative Theatre Awards|Caffe Cino Award]] winning<ref>http://www.nyitawards.com/anr/2006honorees.asp</ref> NYC downtown theatre company first established in 2000, with a mission towards the creation and production of theatrical events based in [[stage combat]] and dark comedy with a comic book edge. They began on the campus of [[Ohio University]], moving to NYC in 2002. The company has been a resident company at Center Stage, NY (2005–2008), [[HERE Arts Center]] (2009–2010), Incubator Arts Project (2011–2013), and The New Ohio Theater & IRT (2013–2015). The company is led by [[artistic director]] [[Qui Nguyen]] and [[Robert Ross Parker]]. Past productions include the cult Off-Off Broadway shows: ''Geek!'', ''The Inexplicable Redemption of Agent G'', ''Alice in Slasherland'', ''Soul Samurai'',<ref>http://www.timeout.com/newyork/articles/theater/71892/soul-samurai</ref> ''Fight Girl Battle World'',<ref>http://www.theatermania.com/content/news.cfm/story/13130</ref> ''Men of Steel'',<ref>http://www.showbusinessweekly.com/archive/429/MenofSteel.shtml</ref> ''Vampire Cowboy Trilogy'',<ref>https://www.amazon.com/dp/0967023467/</ref> and ''Living Dead in Denmark'',<ref>http://www.backstage.com/bso/news_reviews/nyc/review_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=1002503487</ref> which featured special effects by Chuck Varga, co-founder of the shock rock band [[GWAR]]. The first theatre company to ever be sponsored by [[New York Comic Con]], Vampire Cowboys is often credited for being the pioneers of "Geek Theatre",<ref>http://thevillager.com/villager_414/theplaywrights.html</ref> a subgenre of theatre that often incorporates action-adventure, sci-fi, gaming, and/or comic book themes into live theatre. The company was praised by [[The Village Voice]] as "New York's Best Army of Geeks".<ref>http://www.villagevoice.com/bestof/2010/award/best-army-of-geeks-2167593/</ref> The Vampire Cowboys had their work documented in a doctoral dissertation on martial arts on the American stage from [[Tufts University]] in 2011.<ref>{{cite book|last=Langsner|first=Meron|title=Impossible Bodies in Motion: The Representation of Martial Arts on the American Stage|year=2011|publisher=ProQuest|location=Tufts University|pages=209|url=http://gradworks.umi.com/34/75/3475077.html}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.vampirecowboys.com/ Vampire Cowboys Theatre Company website] * [http://www.brooklynrail.org/2007-03/theater/sok-pow-beware-i-the-vampire-cowboys-i/ Feature article from The Brooklyn Rail] * [http://www.offoffonline.com/feature-05042006.html Feature article from OffOffOnline] * [http://www.timeoutny.com/newyork/Details.do?page=1&xyurl=xyl://TONYWebArticles1/557/features/the_not_ready_for_broadway_playwrights.xml Feature from TIMEOUT NEW YORK] * [http://www.unima-usa.org/publications/toc/32_selections2.html Article in ''Puppetry International'']
[[Category:Asian-American theatre]] [[Category:Theatre in New York City]]

page.title: Works by Banksy that have been damaged or destroyed

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2018}} This is a list of damaged or destroyed works of [[guerrilla art]] created by [[Banksy]], which have been removed from their [[In-situ conservation|original locations]] or otherwise [[Vandalism of art|damaged]] or [[Art destruction|destroyed]].
Banksy is an England-based [[graffiti]] artist.
==Removed from their original locations== * Cave art hoax with accompanying exhibit label, hung on a wall in the [[British Museum]], removed after two or three days and subsequently accessioned; in 2005.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/4563751.stm |title=Cave art hoax hits British Museum |work=[[BBC]] |date=19 May 2005 |accessdate=10 March 2011}}</ref> * Two works [[wikt:jetwash|jetwashed]] away and a third work, of a boy holding a stereo and a teddy bear, the subject of legal action opposing its ablation by [[Hackney Council]] in order "to keep streets clean", in [[Dalston]], [[London]]; in 2009.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.standard.co.uk/news/battle-to-stop-new-banksy-being-destroyed-6867249.html|title=Battle to stop new Banksy being destroyed |author=Razaq, Rashid |work=[[Evening Standard]] |date=5 March 2009 |accessdate=10 March 2011}}</ref> * Vulture with fuel pump head on side of a container at Dungeness beach, Kent stolen in early September 2010.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.kentonline.co.uk/kentonline/news/2010/september/9/banksy_art_stolen_at_dungeness.aspx |title=Banksy art stolen at Dungeness |work=[[Kent Messenger]] |date=9 September 2010 |accessdate=10 March 2011}}</ref> * Rat, stolen from an electricity meter box outside the home of a well-known underwear designer in [[Melbourne]], claimed to be by Banksy; the [[Authenticity in art|authenticity]] of this work was questioned, with some calling it a [[Forgery|fake]]; in 2010.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.theage.com.au/victoria/stolen-banksy-a-fake-doubt-cast-on-designers-missing-graffiti-20100617-yicp.html |title=Stolen Banksy a fake? Doubt cast on designer's missing graffiti |author=Levy, Megan |work=[[The Age]] |date=17 June 2010 |accessdate=11 March 2011 |location=Melbourne}}</ref> * [[Mickey Mouse]]-inspired ''Livin' the Dream'', removed from [[Sunset Boulevard]], [[Los Angeles]] and destroyed; in 2011.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://blogs.laweekly.com/informer/2011/02/banksy_hollywood_oscars.php |title=Banksy Art Worth Six Figures Ripped Down from Sunset Boulevard Billboard, Crumpled Up in a Ball |author=Romero, Dennis |work=[[LA Weekly]] |date=17 February 2011 |accessdate=10 March 2011}}</ref> * Mural entitled ''Caution'', detached from a wall in [[Boyle Heights, Los Angeles]]; in 2011.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://blogs.laweekly.com/informer/2011/02/banksy_art_stolen_angeles.php |title=Valuable Banksy Street Art Stolen from East Los Angeles Wall |author=Romero, Dennis |work=[[LA Weekly]] |date=28 February 2011 |accessdate=10 March 2011}}</ref> * ''[[Parachuting Rat]]'' in [[Melbourne]], [[Australia]] was accidentally destroyed in May 2012 by builders installing new plumbing.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2012-05-16/melbourne-builder-destroys-banksy-art/4014514 |title=Banksy rat destroyed by builders |work=Australian Broadcasting Corporation |date=17 May 2012 |accessdate=17 May 2012}}</ref> * ''[[Slave Labour (mural)|Slave Labour]]'', a 2012 mural depicting a child making union flag bunting and regarded as a critical social commentary on the Queen's Diamond Jubilee, prised from the wall of a Poundland shop in [[Wood Green]], [[London Borough of Haringey|Haringey]], North London in 'mysterious circumstances' on 13 February 2013. An attempt to sell it in the US 10 days later, at the Fine Arts Auction Miami art house on 23 February, was halted at the last minute after Haringey residents began a campaign for its return.<ref name="guardianauction">{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2013/feb/23/banksy-missing-mural-auction-stopped |title=Sale of 'stolen' Banksy mural cancelled at 11th hour |publisher=The Guardian |date=23 February 2013 |accessdate=18 April 2013 |location=London |first=Richard |last=Luscombe}}</ref> * ''No Ball Games'', a 2009 mural depicting two children playing [[Catch (game)|catch]] with a sign saying "No Ball Games", was removed from a wall in [[Tottenham]], Haringey, north London in July 2013. It was cut into three pieces, restored and then sold in April 2014 at an exhibition titled "The Stealing Banksy".<ref name="noballgamesauction">{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/art/art-news/10785417/Banksy-condemns-disgusting-Stealing-Banksy-exhibition-on-opening-day.html |title=Banksy condemns 'disgusting' Stealing Banksy exhibition on opening day |publisher=The Telegraph |date=24 April 2014 |accessdate=4 October 2016 |location=London}}</ref> The Sincura Group, the company that had also placed the "Slave Labour" mural up for sale, stated that the mural had "not been appreciated in situ". Local residents and councillors were disappointed by its removal.<ref name="bbcnoballgames">{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-23461396 |title=Banksy's No Ball Games mural removed from Tottenham wall |publisher=BBC |date=26 July 2013 |accessdate=16 April 2014 |location=London}}</ref> * In April 2014, ''Mobile Lovers'' in Bristol (painted onto plyboard) was removed by crowbar, and is currently residing in Broad Plains Boys Club. There is no evidence of legitimate ownership, and the "leader" of the group plans to sell the piece to help gather funding.{{citation needed|date=December 2015}} * A mural depicting a soldier with the face of a Lego figure was detached from its original location at Schleifmühlgasse, Vienna, Austria.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.flickr.com/photos/luxemburger/3163794663 | title=Grafittidiebe | website=flickr.com}}</ref> * A painting of the "Grim Reaper" originally located on the side of [[The Thekla]] in [[Bristol]] was removed as it was decaying. It is now on a long term display at the [[M Shed]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Banksy’s Grim Reaper goes on display at M Shed|url=http://www.bristolmuseums.org.uk/blog/banksy-grim-reaper-thekla/|publisher=Bristol Museums Galleries and Archives|accessdate=28 November 2015}}</ref> * The artwork ''[[Spy Booth]]'' in [[Cheltenham]], [[England]] - said to be a critique of the [[Global surveillance disclosures]] of 2013, was removed and possibly destroyed in August 2016 by persons unknown.<ref>{{cite web|title=Banksy artwork removed from Cheltenham house|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-gloucestershire-37148473|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=4 April 2017}}</ref> This was despite it having gained grade II listed status and retrospective planning permission making its removal illegal.<ref>{{cite web|title=Banksy 'Spy Booth' mural in Cheltenham gets protection|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-gloucestershire-315397673|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=4 April 2017}}</ref> The current whereabouts and condition of the artwork is unknown.
==Concealed or defaced== * In March 2007 one of Banksy's early pieces, a 25 ft-long artwork featuring a collection of blue shapes with the artist's trademark tag, on the side of garages in Albion Road, [[Easton, Bristol]], was mistakenly painted over by graffiti-removal contractors Nordic. They had been asked by Bristol City Council to tackle graffiti adjacent to the Banksy work, but wrongly targeted the piece itself. Within days someone sprayed the words "''Wot no Banksy?''" over the contractors' plain paintwork.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/bristol/6444501.stm|title=Banksy work painted over in error|publisher=BBC|date=13 March 2007|accessdate=21 September 2011}}</ref> * In April 2007 Banksy's famous 2002 piece depicting [[John Travolta]] and [[Samuel L. Jackson]]'s ''[[Pulp Fiction]]'' characters pointing bananas instead of guns, on a wall near Old Street tube station in London, was painted over by London Transport workmen despite having an estimated value of more than £300,000 at the time. Asked to comment on the mural's destruction, a Transport for London spokesman said "Our graffiti removal teams are staffed by professional cleaners not professional art critics."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/6575345.stm|title=Iconic Banksy image painted over|publisher=BBC|date=20 April 2007|accessdate=21 September 2011}}</ref> * In April 2007 a four-year-old wall mural 25 ft long in Cato Street, Easton, Bristol, marketed for sale with its attached house (at 21 Milvart Street) thrown in for free via [http://www.redpropeller.co.uk/ Red Propeller gallery] and was subsequently defaced with red paint. Celebrities had previously expressed interest in buying the work, and the gallery owner contacted Banksy for permission to [[Conservation-restoration|restore]] the work. Banksy however declined the offer, stating that overwriting and defacement was an inevitable reality of street art.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.metro.co.uk/news/46984-banksy-house-art-destroyed |title=Bansky house art destroyed |work=[[Metro (British newspaper)|Metro]] |date=27 April 2007 |accessdate=10 March 2011}}</ref> * In November 2007 a mural of a policeman stopping and searching a young girl in [[Glastonbury]], created in connection with the [[Glastonbury Festival]], was whitewashed over.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk:80/somerset/content/image_galleries/banksy_gallery.shtml?1 |title=Banksy destroyed |publisher=BBC |accessdate=10 March 2011}}</ref> * In 2008 ''The Little Diver'' or ''Diving Bell'', previously [[Conservation-restoration#Caring for cultural heritage|protected]] with a perspex sheet by [[Melbourne City Council]] in Australia, incensing many street artists, was covered with silver paint poured behind the sheet and later tagged with the slogan "Banksy woz ere". The image was almost completely obliterated.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.theage.com.au/national/the-painter-painted-melbourne-loses-its-treasured-banksy-20081213-6xzy.html |title=The painted painted: Melbourne loses its treasured Bansky |author=Houghton, Janae |work=[[The Age]] |date=14 December 2008 |accessdate=10 March 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.theage.com.au/entertainment/art-and-design/guerillas-with-the-mist-breed-banksy-rats-20100428-ts54.html |title=Guerillas with the mist breed Banksy rats |author=Levy, Megan |author2=Hunter, Thomas |date=28 April 2010 |accessdate=11 March 2011 |location=Melbourne |work=The Age}}</ref>
[[File:Bansky one nation under cctv.jpg|thumb|right|''[[One Nation Under CCTV]]'' in 2008]]
* In April 2009 ''[[One Nation Under CCTV]]'', an April 2008 mural, was removed (painted over) after London's [[Westminster City Council]] had stated in October 2008 that it would remove any graffiti, regardless of the reputation of its creator, and specifically stated that Banksy "has no more right to paint graffiti than a child." Robert Davis, chairman of the council planning committee told [[The Times]] newspaper: "If we condone this then we might as well say that any kid with a spray can is producing art."<ref name="SMHOct2008">{{cite news |url= http://www.smh.com.au/news/world/banksy-art-is-graffiti-rules-council/2008/10/24/1224351528852.html |work=The Sydney Morning Herald |title=Banksy art is graffiti, rules town hall |date=24 October 2008 |accessdate=18 April 2013}}</ref> * On 22 June 2009, ''[[Well Hung Lover]]'', on the side of Brook Sexual Health Clinic<ref name=GrafPropPrices>{{cite news |url=http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/features/3187949/Banksy-graffiti-can-push-up-property-price.html |title=Banksy graffiti can push up property prices |publisher=[[The Sun (United Kingdom)]] |date=20 October 2010| accessdate=21 September 2011 |location=London}}</ref> in Park Street, Bristol, and voted for retention by 93% of the public in a 2006 council poll, was spattered with blue paint in an overnight paint bomb attack.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/bristol/8114184.stm |title=Banksy mural defaced with paint |publisher=BBC |accessdate=21 September 2011 |date=23 June 2009}}</ref>
[[File:Banksy MIld Mild West and poster.jpg|thumb|right|''[[The Mild Mild West]]'' in 2007]]
* One of Banksy's earliest, best known and most prominent works, ''[[The Mild Mild West]]'', featuring a teddy bear throwing a Molotov cocktail containing a bunch of flowers at police, located on the side of a building in Cheltenham Road, Bristol, was twice defaced with paint during 2009. It was cleaned up both times, but was damaged in the process; the paint used to attack it is still visible.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/local/bristol/hi/people_and_places/arts_and_culture/newsid_7985000/7985625.stm |title=Banksy art vandalism is 'stupid' |work=[[BBC]] |date=6 April 2009 |accessdate=27 April 2014}}</ref> * In September 2009 a mural of the [[British Royal Family]], featured on the cover of a single by [[Blur (band)|Blur]], was accidentally painted over by workmen employed by [[Hackney Council]], [[London]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/london/8238896.stm |title=Blur Banksy ruined by mistake |work=[[BBC]] |date=4 September 2009 |accessdate=10 March 2011}}</ref> * ''[[Parachuting Rat]]'', one of the last surviving example of Banksy's [[Melbourne]] street art, accidentally painted over by council contractors in March 2010.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.abc.net.au/lateline/content/2010/s2887629.htm |title=Melbourne debates street art |author=Fitzsimmons, Hamish |date=30 April 2010 |work=[[ABC Online]] |accessdate=11 March 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.chinapost.com.tw/asia/australia/2010/04/29/254488/Australian-officials.htm |title=Australian officials apologise over Banksy blunder |work=[[The China Post]] |date=29 April 2010 |accessdate=11 March 2011}}</ref> * In February 2011 a mural behind Westwood Village Urban Outfitters in [[Westwood Village, Los Angeles]], depicting a child holding a machine gun loaded with coloured crayons, was defaced with black paint<ref>{{cite news |url=http://blogs.laweekly.com/informer/2011/02/banksy_art_vandalized.php |title=Banksy Boy-With-Gun Art in Westwood Vandalized |author=Romero, Dennis |work=[[LA Weekly]] |date=19 February 2011 |accessdate=10 March 2011}}</ref> just days before the [[83rd Academy Awards]] for which his documentary film ''[[Exit Through The Gift Shop]]'' had been nominated. * In May 2011 a Banksy piece drawn in October 2010 around an extractor fan on the Grosvenor Hotel in [[Torquay]] was destroyed. It depicted a child drawing a robot. Within a week of its appearance the owners announced plans to cover it with protective perspex amid newspaper speculation that it had increased the value of the property by £150,000.<ref name=GrafPropPrices /> Vandals smashed the perspex screen on 31 May 2011 to attack the mural with paint stripper, removing the child.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-devon-13600013 |title=Banksy art destroyed |publisher=BBC |accessdate=31 May 2011 |date=31 May 2011}}</ref> * On 6 July 2010, ''[[Gorilla in a Pink Mask]]'' (also known as ''Gorilla with Pink Face Mask'') in Fishponds Road, Eastville, Bristol, was painted over by new owners of the building<ref>{{cite news |url=http://sociorobotics.wordpress.com/2011/07/07/banksy-gorilla-in-eastville-bristol-painted-over/ |title=Banksy 'Gorilla with Pink Face Mask' painted over |author=Meadows, Dean |work=[[Sociorobotics]] |date=7 July 2011 |accessdate=15 July 2011}}</ref> – by sheer coincidence on the same day that Bristol Zoo Gardens celebrated its 175th anniversary with "''Wow! Gorillas''", an event placing decorated life-size gorillas around the city for 10 weeks.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wowgorilla.org.uk/wow-gorillas |title=Wow! Gorillas – Bristol Zoo |publisher=Bristol, Clifton & West of England Zoological Society Ltd. |accessdate=20 September 2011}}</ref> * In October 2011, Banksy's ''Sniper'' on Upper Maudlin Street, Bristol was vandalised by Graffiti artists that support [[King Robbo]] spraying Team Robbo with black spray paint.<ref>{{cite web|title="Team Robbo" defaces Banksy's sniper in Bristol|url=https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2011/oct/03/banksy-classic-defaced-bristol?newsfeed=true|accessdate=19 March 2012}}</ref> * In 2011 a Banksy work in Boston's [[Chinatown, Boston|Chinatown]] was graffitied and partially painted over. * On 31 December 2013 ''Praying Boy'', just off of Main Street in [[Park City, Utah]] was graffitied and 90% painted over. It was one of four created during the 2010 [[Sundance Film Festival]]. He was in Park City promoting his documentary that was featured in the festival ''[[Exit Through The Gift Shop]]''.<ref>{{cite web|title=" Vandals attack Banksy" defaces Banksy's Praying Boy in Park City|url=http://www.parkrecord.com/City/ci_24832961/Vandals-attack-Banksy-pieces-on-Main|accessdate= 4 January 2014 }}</ref> * In August 2013 the Banksy which was defaced in 2012 depicting a child drawing a robot at the Grosvenor Hotel in [[Torquay]] was covered up by the hotel owners as an attempt to stop vandals doing more damage. In 2012 the image of the boy was damaged by vandals throwing acid on it, all that remained was the robot. The robot has now been boarded up and preserved underneath, the hotel owners claim. * Several other Banksy works in New York City were defaced in October 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2460471/Banksy-sees-street-artworks-vandalized-New-York.html|title=Two more Banksy pieces damaged|publisher=|accessdate=8 November 2016}}</ref> * In October 2014, an "Anti-immigration birds" mural painted over after [[Clacton-on-Sea]]'s local council received a complaint, it was not then known that the work was Banksy's.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-england-essex-29446232|title=Banksy anti-immigration birds mural in Clacton-on-Sea destroyed|date=1 October 2014|publisher=|accessdate=8 November 2016|via=www.bbc.com}}</ref> * In February 2015 a [[Bomb Hugger]] stencil Banksy sprayed 2002 in [[Hamburg]] was destroyed by the paint that dripped down from a graffiti above.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Granz |first1=Kim-Christopher |title=Einziges Hamburger Banksy Street-Art durch Unbekannten zerstört |url=https://designlovr.de/magazine/e/banksy-street-art-hamburg-zerstoert/ |website=Designlovr |accessdate=19 October 2018}}</ref> * On 15 October 2015, the artwork painted by Banksy in Harringay, London depicting the Turkish President [[Recep Tayyip Erdogan]] and his son [[Necmettin Bilal Erdoğan]] portrayed as thieves running off with a big sack full of money, was partially painted over covering both of their faces. * On January 2016, the Banksy mural at the entrance to the former [[Calais Jungle]] refugee camp, which depicted [[Apple Inc.|Apple]] founder, [[Steve Jobs]], as a refugee, was defaced with the words "LONDON CALLiNG", with Jobs' body taking the place of the ''i''; the body of the ''i'' was not painted but the dot was, partially, covering Jobs' head; further defacement has followed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/2016/01/28/banksy-steve-jobs-mural-calais-jungle-defaced_n_9097626.html|date=29 January 2016|accessdate=12 July 2017|title=Banksy’s Steve Jobs Mural In Calais ‘Jungle’ Defaced With ‘London Calling’ Graffiti}}</ref>
==Demolished== * ''The New Pollution'' in St Werburghs, Bristol, was knocked down in 2006 by developers in order to build a new block of flats.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/news/64488/Banksys-100k-art-wall-lost.html |title=Banky's 100k art wall lost |work=[[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]] |date=23 September 2006 |accessdate=15 September 2011 |location=London |first=John |last=Coles}}</ref> * ''No Loitrin'' on Essex Street in Cambridge, Massachusetts; removed by [[sandblasting]].
==''Better Out Than In''== {{Main|Better Out Than In}} Most of the works that make up the October 2013 ''[[Better Out Than In]]'' series in [[New York City]] have been [[Defacement (vandalism)|defaced]] or destroyed, some just hours after the piece was unveiled.<ref name=nytimes_welcome>{{cite news|title=Banksy’s New York Welcome|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/10/16/opinion/banksys-new-york-welcome.html|work=[[New York Times]]|accessdate=21 October 2013|date=15 October 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Janeczko|first=Jane|title=Banksy Piece In Queens Defaced By Other Graffiti Artists|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/10/15/banksy-destroyed_n_4101145.html|work=[[Huffington Post]]|accessdate=21 October 2013|date=15 October 2013}}</ref> * At least one defacement was identified as done by a competing artist, OMAR NYC, who spray-painted over Banksy's red mylar balloon piece in [[Red Hook, Brooklyn|Red Hook]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Janeczko|first=Jane|title=Banksy Hater, OMAR NYC, Defaces Art In Red Hook|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/10/08/banksy-hater-defaces_n_4065250.html|work=[[Huffington Post]]|accessdate=21 October 2013|date=8 October 2013}}</ref> OMAR NYC also defaced some of Banksy's work in May 2010.<ref>{{cite web|last=Turco|first=Bucky|title=BANKSY THOROUGHLY RAGGED|url=http://animalnewyork.com/2010/banksy-thoroughly-ragged/|work=Animal New York|accessdate=21 October 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Dobkin|first=Jake|title=Banksy Gets Dissed|url=http://gothamist.com/2010/05/18/banksy_gets_dissed.php?#photo-1|work=[[Gothamist]]|accessdate=21 October 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131010072201/http://gothamist.com/2010/05/18/banksy_gets_dissed.php#photo-1|archivedate=10 October 2013}}</ref> * On 2 October 2013, on [[Allen Street]] in New York City's [[Chinatown, Manhattan|Chinatown]], one of Banksy's works that was part of ''Better Out Than In'' was painted over, the day after Banksy unveiled the piece.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://gothamist.com/2013/10/02/photos_banksys_lower_east_side_piec.php#photo-1|title=Welcome To New York: Banksy's New PIece Colossally Dissed|publisher=|accessdate=8 November 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161021093418/http://gothamist.com/2013/10/02/photos_banksys_lower_east_side_piec.php#photo-1|archivedate=21 October 2016}}</ref> * On 7 October 2013, at the intersection of New York City's [[Bowery]] and [[Delancey Street|Delancey streets]] on the [[Lower East Side]], a stencil by Banksy was tagged over by three vandals.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/music-arts/graffiti-artists-deface-banksy-artwork-east-side-article-1.1476932|title=Music - NY Daily News|publisher=|accessdate=8 November 2016}}</ref>
As a result of the continued defacement, fans have been rushing to the sites of the installments as soon as they are announced.<ref name=nytimes_race>{{cite news|last=Barron|first=James|title=Racing to See Banksy Graffiti, While It Can Still Be See|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/10/16/nyregion/racing-to-see-banksy-graffiti-while-it-can-still-be-seen.html?_r=0|work=[[New York Times]]|accessdate=21 October 2013|date=15 October 2013}}</ref> A group of men took advantage of this and threatened to deface a stencil painting of a beaver in [[East New York]], charging money for people to take photographs.<ref>{{cite web|last=Jefferson |first=Cord |title=These Men Are Now Charging People to Look at Banksy's Latest Stencil |url=http://gawker.com/these-men-are-now-charging-people-to-look-at-banksys-l-1443562694 |work=[[Gawker]] |accessdate=21 October 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131019141644/http://gawker.com/these-men-are-now-charging-people-to-look-at-banksys-l-1443562694 |archivedate=19 October 2013 |df= }}</ref> The continued defacement has prompted some to take matters into their own hands by guarding the works, others restoring them once defaced.<ref>{{cite news|last=Caulfield|first=Philip|title=Banksy fans restore Williamsburg ‘geishas’ after tussle with tagger|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/new-york/banksy-fans-restore-williamsburg-geishas-tussle-tagger-article-1.1488985|work=[[New York Daily News]]|accessdate=21 October 2013}}</ref> Property owners have also gone to some measures to protect the art, including hiring 24-hour guards and installing roll down gates that cover the art.<ref>{{cite news|title=NYC building owner installs gate, hires guards to save work by elusive graffiti artist Banksy|url=https://webcache.googleusercontent.com/search?q=cache:lMkzIr_JBfIJ:www.sunjournal.com/news/0001/11/30/nyc-building-owner-installs-gate-hires-guards-save/1439976+&cd=1&hl=en&ct=clnk&gl=us|agency=Associated Press|publisher=[[Sun Journal (Lewiston)|Sun Journal]] (Maine)|accessdate=21 October 2013}}</ref>
==''Girl with Balloon'' transformed into ''Love is in the Bin''== ''[[Girl with Balloon]]'', a framed art piece, was sold for $1.4 million at a [[Sotheby's]] auction in London on 5 October 2018. Immediately after the auction ended, a mechanism hidden in the frame was triggered by [[remote control]] and partially shredded the piece.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/10/06/arts/design/uk-banksy-painting-sothebys.html?action=click&module=Top%20Stories&pgtype=Homepage|title=Banksy Painting Self-Destructs After Fetching $1.4 Million at Sotheby’s|accessdate=6 October 2018}}</ref> Banksy later explained that he had built the shredder into the painting several years before it went up for auction,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/art/news/banksy-explains-prank-shredded-girl-with-balloon-sothebys-auction-a8572956.html|title=Banksy explains why and how he destroyed artwork that had just been sold for £1m|work=The Independent|access-date=2018-10-08|language=en-GB}}</ref> and named the new artwork created by the shredding ''[[Love is in the Bin]]''.
==See also== * [[Iconoclasm]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
{{Banksy}}
[[Category:Art crime|Banksy]] [[Category:Vandalized works of art|Banksy]] [[Category:Works by Banksy]]

{{More citations needed|date=August 2011}} {{Infobox company | name = Zemaitis Guitars | logo = | caption = | type = Private | industry = Guitar Brand | foundation = [[London]], England ({{Start date and age|1955}}) | founder = [[Tony Zemaitis]] | location_city = [[Paso Robles, California]] | area_served = Worldwide | key_people = [[Greg Timmons]] | products = [[Electric Guitars]], [[Bass guitars]], [[Acoustic Guitars]] | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | num_employees = | parent = [[Kanda Shokai Corporation]] | divisions = | subsid = | footnotes = | location_country = United States | homepage = http://zemaitisguitarcompany.com/ }} [[Image:Zemaitis Pearl Top.jpg|thumb|Pearl Front guitar]]
'''Zemaitis Guitars''' is a US brand based out of [[Paso Robles, California]]. The company's guitars are based on designs by the British [[luthier]] [[Tony Zemaitis]]. Zemaitis Guitar Company is owned and manufactured by [[Kanda Shokai Corporation]] in [[Tokyo, Japan]]. Zemaitis is globally known for its unique metal front guitars and pearl inlay guitars. The brand's slogan is "Art with Strings" The slogan was because Zemaitis became not only about the stunning look of their guitars, but the amazing tone to match. Zemaitis has had many notable players use their guitars throughout the years such as [[Ronnie Wood]], [[James Hetfield]], [[Ronnie Lane]], [[Keith Richards]], [[Rich Robinson]], [[Keith Nelson (musician)|Keith Nelson]] and [[Gilby Clark]]. Today Zemaitis continues to work with a variety of influential guitarists like [[Joe Louis Walker]], [[Christian Martucci]], [[Ashes (guitarist)|Ashes]], [[Clay Cook]] and [[Ken Mochikoshi]].
== Notable players == * [[Keith Richards]] of [[the Rolling Stones]] * [[Ronnie Wood]] * [[Andy McCoy]] of [[Hanoi Rocks]] * [[Greg Lake]] of [[Emerson, Lake & Palmer]] and [[King Crimson]] * [[Ronnie Lane]] of [[Faces (band)|Faces]] *[[Mary Hopkin]] * [[Joe Walsh]] * [[James Honeyman-Scott]] of [[The Pretenders]] * [[Richie Sambora]] of [[Bon Jovi]] * [[Gary Grainger]] of [[Rod Stewart]] * [[Simon Hinkler]] of [[The Mission UK]] * [[Dave Sharp]] of [[The Alarm]] * Charlie Starr of [[Blackberry Smoke]] * [[James Hetfield]] of [[Metallica]] * Rich Robinson of The Black Crowes * Miku Kobato of [[Band-Maid]] * [[Geddy Lee]] of [[Rush (band)|Rush]] appeared with a 1992 model Zemaitis bass on the band's R40 tour. * Yoshi of [[Aldious]] * [[Dave Dalton]] of [[Screaming Bloody Marys]] * [[Mike Oldfield]]
==References== <references />
==External links== *[http://zemaitisguitar.com/ Official U.S. Website] *[http://www.zemaitis-guitars.com/ Official International Website]

revision.text:
{{italic title}} '''''Ça ira''''' was the [[Belgium|Belgian]] monthly magazine that featured avant-garde art, literature and politics.
==History and profile== ''Ça Ira'' was founded by a [[art group|group]] of young artists, who came out of the smoking war-wrecked world of 1919 with a new élan. The title ''Ça ira'' comes from a song of the French Revolution ([[:fr:Ah! ça ira|article in French]], translated as: "We will win!").<ref>{{cite book|author1=Peter Brooker|author2=Sascha Bru|author3=Andrew Thacker|author4=Christian Weikop|title=The Oxford Critical and Cultural History of Modernist Magazines: Europe 1880 - 1940|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bvsfioiQ8k8C&pg=PA331|accessdate=5 May 2015|date=19 May 2013|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-965958-6|page=331}}</ref> Twenty editions were published in [[Antwerp]]<ref name=mus>{{cite book|author=Francis Mus|editor=Pieter Boulogne|title=Translation and Its Others. Selected Papers of the CETRA Research Seminar in Translation Studies 2007|date=2008|url=http://www.arts.kuleuven.be/cetra/papers/files/mus.pdf|accessdate=30 January 2015|chapter=Internationalization in Belgian Literary Periodicals after WWI. Outline of a Research Project}}</ref> from April 1920 to January 1923.<ref>{{cite web|title=Ça Ira|url=http://monoskop.org/%C3%87a_ira|work=Monoskop|accessdate=20 September 2014}}</ref>
The members (many of whom later achieved great fame and notoriety) included [[Paul Colin (journalist)|Paul Colin]], [[Theo van Doesburg]], the young artist [[Maurice van Essche]] who was the leader of the group,<ref name=mus/> Abel Lurkin, Paul Neuhuys, Arthur Pétronio, [[Charles Plisnier]], Han Ryner, while very appealing [[dada]] and [[expressionist]] woodcuts and linos were added by [[Floris Jespers]], Paul Joostens, [[Frans Masereel]], [[Jan Cockx]], [[Jozef Cantré]], Karel Maes and Jozef Peeters. One finds incidental contributions by [[Paul Van Ostaijen]], [[Paul Éluard]], [[Francis Picabia]], Pound, [[Iwan Goll]], [[Blaise Cendrars]] and Kassak.
==See also== * [[List of magazines in Belgium]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Ca Ira}} [[Category:1920 establishments in Belgium]] [[Category:1923 disestablishments in Belgium]] [[Category:Art magazines]] [[Category:Belgian magazines]] [[Category:Belgian monthly magazines]] [[Category:Defunct magazines of Belgium]] [[Category:Defunct political magazines]] [[Category:Defunct literary magazines of Europe]] [[Category:French-language magazines]] [[Category:Magazines established in 1920]] [[Category:Magazines disestablished in 1923]] [[Category:Media in Antwerp]]
{{Europe-poli-mag-stub}}
